title: Quantifying Protein Dynamics at Solid-Liquid Interfaces with Atomic Force Microscopy and Machine Learning
content: Proteins are the building blocks of nature, having innate abilities to assemble into complex hierarchal structures with diverse functions. More recently, scientists have begun to harness the self-assembly of these molecules to develop new biomimetic materials with applications in health, energy, and environment. However, creating two-dimensional (2D) protein architectures at solid-liquid interfaces in a pre-designed manner is still highly challenging. The energy landscape arising from the interplay between protein-protein and protein-surface interactions can determine the dynamics and final organization of proteins at solid-liquid interfaces but remains unclear. To explore how the energy landscape responds to solution conditions and environmental stimuli at solid-liquid interfaces, in-situ characterization with high temporal and spatial resolution, in combination with statistical analysis, is required.
